The Chapter on the Elephant
The Perfection of Morality
The Story of the Mother’s Keeper
“When I was a forest elephant,
a mother’s keeper,
There was no one on earth
equal to me in virtue.
A forest ranger saw me in the forest
and reported me to the king:
‘Your Majesty, in the forest
lives a young elephant.
He has no need of a keeper
or of a goad.
As soon as he is caught by the trunk,
he will come here of his own accord.’
Having heard his words,
the king was delighted.
He sent for a trainer,
a skilled teacher.

analyzed: gantvā saḥ hatthi damakaḥ  addasa padumassare
translated: The trainer went🔽and saw me in a lotus pond
pulling out lotus roots
to feed my mother.
Recognizing my virtue and virtue,🔽he considered my characteristics
and said, ‘Come, son,’
and caught me with his trunk.

analyzed: yam me tadā pākatika  sarīra anugatam bala
translated: The strength that I then had,
which was in my body,🔽is today equal to the strength
of a thousand elephants.
If I were to get angry with them,
to seize me when I am near;
I am able to endure them,
as long as it is only human ropes.
But even though I am protecting my virtue,
and fulfilling the perfection of virtue,
I do not have a change of heart
when he puts me in the cage.
If they were to beat me there
with axes and spears,
I would not be angry with them,
for fear of breaking my virtue.”
The Story of Mātāposaka, the First.
